title: New River Path Walking Route

images.title: Dudley Miles [CC BY-SA 4.0 (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0)], via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: New River in King's Meads, a nature reserve near Hertford managed by the Herts and Middlesex Wildlife Trust

images.title: Mike Ryan / The New River, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The New River near its start on the River Lee

images.title: Nigel Cox / The New River, Stanstead St. Margarets, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The New River, Stanstead St. Margarets.  The New River is something of a misnomer since it is neither a river nor new. It is an aqueduct built under the direction of Sir Hugh Myddleton between 1607 and 1612 to bring fresh drinking water from Chadwell and Amwell Springs near Ware about 40 miles down the Lee Valley to London

images.title: Stephen Dawson / New River Aqueduct, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: New River Aqueduct. The New River was opened in 1613 to carry fresh water from near Hertford to Islington. In maintaining the contour, it had many large loops: in 1859 a 3½ mile loop through the Whitewebbs estate was cut off with embankments and this aqueduct over Turkey Brook. Just to the right (north) of here is where Thames Water extract water from the New River and pipe it into the King George V reservoir prior to treatment in Walthamstow.

images.title: Stephen Dawson / New River, Bullsmore Lane
images.caption: Bullsmore Lane. The New River was built in the 17th century to take drinking water from near Hertford to Islington.

images.title: The original uploader was StephenDawson at English Wikipedia., CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: This brick building known as New Gauge is the start of the New River with water pouring from the River Lea into the New River. Extraction of this water caused hostility with boatmen and mill-owners, who both claimed there was insufficient water in the Lea as a result.

description: Follow the man made New River from Hertford to Islington on this easy waterside walk. There's much to enjoy on this walk including regular views of the River Lea and riverside Nature Reserves. The walk passes through Hoddesdon, Rye Meads RSPB Nature Reserve, Cheshunt , Enfield and Finsbury Park with urban sections towards the end of the walk. In the Hertford area the river runs parallel to the Lea Valley Walk which follows the towpath of the River Lea Navigation canal. It's a nice way of extending your walk or creating a circular route around the Hertford and Ware area.
